title: How do native speakers learn English grammar? - Quora

response.answer_text: Native speakers learn “grammar” in two ways. The first way is a natural way. The second way is by the same kind of book study in school that foreign students have to learn English grammar. The study of grammar is not the best way to learn English. However, if you know some English and some grammar, it helps in the study of vocabulary. Before the native speaker ever learns grammar, songs and poems and nursery rhymes have been learned. These develop memory in the mind about the way sentences are made. That is why speaking is a “natural” process. Here is The Shadow Method. It is referred to as a “shadow” because the person practicing with the students says a word or phrase out loud, and the students repeat the word or phrase. By practicing the same lesson every day, and repeating the words or a few words at a time, the students learn how to read and recognize the words. Of course, the children must be given a paper with all of the lesson on it. Like this one: ————————————————- “Hickory dickory dock. The mouse ran up the clock. The clock struck one. The mouse ran down. Hickory dickory dock.”  The native speaker knows how words “sound” even before learning what the words actually mean. Hickory is a kind of tree, but dickory, and dock, are not actual words that mean something. They are nonsense sounds. They are silly sounds. They are there because the sounds are “fun” to say. Before the native speaker knows anything about grammar at all, they memorize the pattern of: “The clock struck one.” Which is the pattern of (Definite Article + Noun + Verb + Number) (Number or some other qualifier such as big, small, good, bad, and so forth and so on.) The pattern is memorized. Watch the pattern. 1 The clock struck one. 2 The mouse ran down. 3 The way is long. 4 The way is short. 5 The words are short. 6 The words are long. 7 The words are big. 8 The words are small. 9 The nouns are hard. 10 The nouns are easy. 11 The verbs are hard. 12 The verbs are easy. 13 The room is big. 14 The room is small. 15 The teacher is mad. 16 The teacher is nice. 17 The food is good. 18 The food is bad. 19 The book is here. 20 The pencil is there. The native speaker knows this, without ever studying any grammar at all. In a similar way, the native speaker learns to form questions and answer them, without studying grammar. 125 It is not easy to do. 126 Some things can be hard to do. 127 There are different ways of doing things. 128 There are good things and there are bad things. 129 Do you like doing this? 130 I like doing this. 131 All of us like doing this. 132 Think about this. 133 Think about that. 134 Find this. 134 Find that. 135 Find the answer. 136 Find the problem. 137 Find the solution. 138 Find the Verbs. 139 Find the Nouns. 140 Discover the secret. 141 Discover the sentences that will help. 142 Discover the sentences that will teach. 143 Discover the sentences that we can speak. 144 Discover the sentences that develop our ability. 145 I have the ability to speak. 146 You have the ability to speak. 147 We have the ability to write. 148 I can write words, sentences, paragraphs, pages, and books. 149 Look at the words. 150 Look at the parts of speech. 152 Look at the Verbs. 153 The Verbs are important to know. 154 I want to know the important things. 155 You want to know the important things. 156 We need to know the important things. ————————— By the time the native speaker gets in school, they have learned a basic vocabulary, without ever hearing or seeing anything at all about grammar. It is also why repetition is emphasized for students of English. The native speaker usually does not have to “think” about what they say. They say what they want to say because of the memory of the way sentences are formed. When certain kinds of songs are learned, such as the slow ballads and so forth, the memory of the rising and falling tones is used in an automatic way, without “thought”. By the time a native speaker studies grammar in school, they have confidence in speaking, even though they have only a limited knowledge about the Parts of Speech or the knowledge about phrases, clauses, and tenses in grammar. Those only become necessary as knowledge, when the native speaker needs to write things for school, or college. Not every person will require an advanced vocabulary. Only a few people are going to find it necessary to use English in a matter consistent with the composition of nonfiction communication. Speaking the language for everyday use, is a very easy thing to do. Writing the language to communicate ideas is a skill that some can show in their high school studies. Writing is done on a more advanced level in college. This however, requires skill in the form of developing what is called an academic vocabulary. [See: Academic Word List] The foreign student can struggle with both spoken and written English. Why is that so often the case? Sometimes, I think it is for the very reason that they are taught English as a study in grammar. Study by repetition and memory is different. When a person studies grammar, they are required to “think”. It is also true that they are required to think about an “abstract concept”.  And so there is a difficulty when a foreign student seeks to improve their speaking and writing ability by getting help or advice from a native speakers. If the only way to learn the language, is thought of as the study of grammar, the foreign student will think; “I need help with grammar.” They will ask frequently. “How can I learn grammar?” “What is the best way to learn grammar?” “Can a native speaker give me tips on learning grammar?”  When someone tries to help the foreign student by suggesting that they learn the English language by different methods, there can be a wall of misunderstanding, and this wall is that the foreign student rejects all such help, because …they have learned that one learns English by the study of grammar. The result is that the foreign student speaks with difficulty, and writes with an even greater difficulty. So the student goes to websites on the Internet, and they ask for help. Obviously, the grammar lessons are only helpful to a certain point. The student asks for help, thinking that the difficulty is solved easily. They think like this: “The native speakers will understand my difficulty. They will advise me and help me to know what I should do.” What happens then, is that the native speakers either repeat what they have learned. They tell the student to “learn grammar”. Sometimes they tell the student to; “Read Everything!” Almost as bad is the advice to “Read Novels.” All of which shows that in the advice given, the foreign student is shown that the native speaker, actually does not know how to teach the study of the language. If I tell a student, “Read everything,”; I am basically saying; “Go find everything out for yourself, and do it the hard way, because I do not know how to teach you.”  Review: What I have written is that: (a) Native speakers do not learn their language by the study of grammar. (b) Native speakers do learn their language by repetition. (c) Native speakers learn to write their language at an advanced or academic level by using synonyms for the Most Common Words and these synonyms can be found in the Academic Word lists as either the Noun form of a Verb, or the Verb Form of a Noun. (d) Foreign students of English think that if they study grammar more and more and more and more and more, they will finally speak well and write well. It is not true. Students can be victimized again and again. Worse, they can be charged money for doing it. See Phonogram Page | Daily Phonics Practice WORD FORMATION

To be honest, we don’t learn grammar, at least not the way ESL students do. We can easily graduate high school and go to university, earn any number of degrees, and never once hear the term “phrasal verb,” “conditional,” or discuss any names of verb tenses or expressions beyond irregular past tenses and past participles. Focus is on punctuation, capitalization, some basic parts of speech, and spelling, spelling, spelling. It’s even its very own subject in elementary school. In high school we’re taught to “tighten” writing which is to minimize words. English can become very “cluttered.” Even though, we don’t learn about phrasal verbs, we’re taught not to use “common” verbs or end sentences with prepositions unless we absolutely must. Latin and French based terms are considered more refined or academic. Germanic words we do not even bother discussing. Fire, happiness, bad—boring. Flame, joy, horrible—-much prettier. Inferno, felicity, malevolent—intense. We try to avoid run-on sentences, learn to clarify with parallel structure, and place words as close to their modifiers as possible. All of this is if we’re lucky. As an affectation, many native speakers will try to sound like they possess good grammar skills by using adverb forms when adjectives are better, and “I” instead of “me,” even in the predicate. Even people with Master’s degrees would probably think this sentence is fine: “The gardener keeps the roses beautifully for my husband and I to enjoy.” But under even the smallest amount of scrutiny it needs two crucial corrections: “The gardener keeps the roses beautiful for my husband and me to enjoy.” People don’t learn about the nature of linking verbs, and how they connect the subject to descriptors in the predicate. Even how subject and object pronouns work is a lost cause. People think that descriptors in the predicate can never go with the subject, and that saying “me” is always incorrect, even rude, in conjunction with another noun or pronoun. Would anyone really describe any of the methods of “keeping” a garden as "beautiful?” Is shoveling dirt, spreading fertilizer, squatting down, or sweating in a hothouse able to be done “beautifully?” Clearly, the writer wants to comment on the garden being beautiful. “Keep” allows this by linking the subject to the predicate. Would anyone ever say “The gardener keeps the roses beautifully for I to enjoy?” No person in the world would ever say this sentence. Yet, somehow adding "my husband” makes this sound correct. I have read sentences through internal correspondence in top media companies, proofread it out of press releases, and heard it straight from the mouths of university professors.
